Title: Dynamics of cognitive functions in ageing and their relationship to education level
Abstract: © 2018 Ima-Press Publishing House. All Rights Reserved.Age-related cognitive changes in the Russian population have not been sufficiently studied. Objective: to assess the time course of changes in cognitive functions (CF) in two serial measurements 9 years apart in the urban population of middle, elder, and senile age and their relationship to education level. Patients and methods: A random male and female sample of 45-69-year-old Novosibirsk residents (n=9360; HAPIEE project) was surveyed. CF was tested by standard methods. Resurvey was conducted in a random subsample (n=1663) included in this analysis. The mean follow-up period was 8.8 years (SD 1.1). Results and discussion: The test for semantic verbal fluency revealed its dynamic decline in all age groups, which was steeper in women than in men (p<0.001). Persons aged 70 years and older showed negative changes in memory, verbal fluency, and attention (p<0.001). Persons with primary (6%) and vocational (26%) education had steeper rates of decline in delayed recall (p=0.011; 0.038) than those with university education (35%). Conclusion: It is established that a dynamic decrease in CF begins at the age of 55-59 years; it is steeper among those aged 70 years and older. An age-related decline in memory function is accelerated in persons with lower educational levels.
